DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US VP Pence said President Trump is determined to build China relationship based on candor, fairness and mutual respect, while he added US is not seeking confrontation with China and is seeking a level playing field. Pence also said President Trump remains optimistic that structural reforms in China can be reached and that the US will continue to seek better relations with China, while Pence added if US and China can get an economic relationship right, they can make progress on other issues. Furthermore, Pence commented that Hong Kong is an example of what can happen when China embraces liberty and said Beijing has increased interventions in HK, curtailing rights and liberties guaranteed in its international agreement. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin tweeted about US VP Pence's speech in which he believes Pence spoke mainly positive on improving relations. (Twitter)

China is willing to buy USD 20bln worth of US farm goods in the first year of the trade deal and would mull boosting purchases further in new rounds of talks, while reports added that in the second year of a potential final deal when all punitive tariffs are removed, those purchases could rise to USD 40bln - USD 50bln. (Newswires)

BoJ is considering refraining from extra stimulus at its October meeting, but will look for a fresh way to show its continued readiness to take action, according to people familiar with the matter. (Newswires) 

 

UK

UK PM Johnson is calling for an election on 12 December, under the fixed term parliament act which would need 2/3 of MPs (434) to vote in favour, while it was also reported the government is to table motion for GE on Monday and that Parliament can still study and pass the WAB, as long as they agree to an election on 12 December. Furthermore, the government was said to have threatened to go on strike if opposition Labour refuse a December 12th election on Monday and it also officially pulled the November 6th budget. (Twitter/The Sun)

UK opposition party Labour is to reject PM Johnson’s offer for an early election and is said to have told Labour MPs to abstain on Monday's election vote but later stated they will back a general election if a no-deal Brexit is taken off the table. (The Sun/Sky)

EU is considering UK PM Johnson’s call to get Parliament onboard for 12 December election and might wait to announce its decision on length of new Brexit extension on Monday, while a separate report also noted that EU27 envoys are unlikely to decide on Brexit delay tomorrow and may decide on Monday or Tuesday but are seeking more clarity. (Newswires/BBC)

Finnish PM Rinne stated that a majority or maybe all of EU states are in favour of a Brexit extension and suggested it appears the EU can decide a extension in writing, while EU Commission President in waiting Von der Leyen noted that the length is yet to be decided. (Newswires)

Bank of England reportedly proposed cutting capital requirements at credit unions by a quarter, adding that Brexit will give more room to simplify rules. (Newswires)

 

EU

  • EU ECB Deposit Rate (Oct) -0.50% vs. Exp. -0.50% (Prev. -0.50%). (Newswires)
  • EU ECB Refinancing Rate (Oct) 0.00% vs. Exp. 0.00% (Prev. 0.00%)
  • EU ECB Marginal Lending Rate (Oct) 0.25% vs. Exp. 0.25% (Prev. 0.25%)

ECB maintained its guidance that it expects the key ECB interest rates to remain at their present or lower levels until it has seen the inflation outlook robustly converge to a level sufficiently close to, but below, 2% within its projection horizon, and such convergence has been consistently reflected in underlying inflation dynamics.

ECB's Draghi said the Governing Council sees the need for highly accommodative policy for a prolonged time and stands ready to adjust instruments. Draghi also said data signals moderate but positive growth in H2, while he added that risks remain on the downside and that the slowdown reflects weak trade, as well as global uncertainties.

  • EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Oct) 51.8 vs. Exp. 51.9 (Prev. 51.6)
  • EU Markit Comp Flash PMI (Oct) 50.2 vs. Exp. 50.3 (Prev. 50.1)
  • German Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Oct) 41.9 vs. Exp. 42 (Prev. 41.7)
  • German Markit Services Flash PMI (Oct) 51.2 vs. Exp. 52 (Prev. 51.4)
  • German Markit Comp Flash PMI (Oct) 48.6 vs. Exp. 48.8 (Prev. 48.5)

 

FX

Swedish Riksbank Rate -0.25% vs. Exp. -0.25% (Prev. -0.25%). Riksbank said its forecast indicates that the interest rate will most probably be raised in December to zero percent and noted that uncertainty over the development of economic activity as well as inflation abroad and in Sweden is considerable, while it added the forecast for the repo rate has therefore been revised downwards and indicated that the interest rate will be unchanged for a prolonged period after the expected rise in December. (Newswires)

US

  • US Markit Services PMI Flash (Oct) 51 vs. Exp. 51 (Prev. 50.9)

  • US Durable Goods (Sep) -1.1% vs. Exp. -0.8% (Prev. 0.2%, Rev. 0.3%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Microsoft (MSFT) reported strong earnings, with a slightly slower than expected growth rate in Azure as the only nagging point, seeing it bolster indices on the day. Tesla (TSLA) surged to highs of 20% in after-market trade following earnings which showed a surprise profit beat on EPS, and noting its Shanghai Gigafactory is working ahead of schedule, as is its Model Y, where it expects production expected by summer next year. Xilinx (XLNX) ultimately moved lower after guiding Q4 revenue well below estimates, although caveat by suggesting Q4 would be a trough. Lam Research (LRCX) beat on top and bottom line, forecasts the bottom range of its Q2 EPS and revenue guidance above street expectation. The strong figures and guidance led a boost to the semiconductor space which saw the SOX outperform its sub-index peers on Thursday. Both figures from LRCX & TSLA led gains to the Nasdaq 100, which outperformed its US peers. Align Technology (ALGN) traded higher following a beat on both EPS & revenue. Twitter (TWTR) plummeted over 20% on Thursday at one point on EPS and revenue misses, citing technical bugs hitting its top line. Baxter (BAX) traded lower as it announced an internal investigation due to financial misstatements. eBay (EBAY) lower despite EPS beat, due to softer guidance. PayPal (PYPL) surged despite softer guidance but a strong revenue print. Ford (F) tumbled as it cut its guidance, although the quarter was okay. S&P 500 0.2% at 3010, NASDAQ-100 1% at 7967, Dow Jones -0.1% at 26806.

The T-Note again traded sideways in the lacklustre session, at least from a risk appetite perspective. The much feared/anticipated VP Pence speech on China took a rather balanced stance and provided no further indication for participants on how the trade war will pan out. The ECB was also a non-event given the last meeting’s fireworks. Earnings were mixed too, seeing equity bourses edge slightly higher, again little to sway participants either in or out of the debt complex. The US 7-year auction was fairly solid, stopping through by 0.7bps, covering above the 6-auction average, with a strong takedown, too – although the TPLEX didn’t blink. US T-note (Z9) settled half a tick lower at 129.27.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 24th October 2019: Market sideways as ECB non-event and VP Pence takes balanced tone on key speech
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries flat, crude up, dollar up
  • REAR VIEW: VP Pence strikes progressive tone whilst scrutinising HK; ECB provides no changes, nor clues
  • COMING-UP: Data: German Consumer Sentiment and Ifo, Baker Hughes. Earnings: Verizon Communications, Phillips 66, Charter Communications, Royal Caribbean, Aon, Ab InBev, Phillips, Unilever, Barclays.

* US VP PENCE'S CHINA SPEECH: US VP Pence said Trump is determined to build China relationship based on candour, fairness and mutual respect; US will no longer hope that economic engagement alone will transform China's into a free and open society, respecting rule of law. Says US is not seeking confrontation with China, nor to limit China's development, it is seeking a level playing field. Trump administration not seeking to decouple US economically from China, Pence said. The VP on Hong Kong, said it is an example of what can happen when China embraces liberty, though Beijing has increased interventions in HK, curtailing rights and liberties guaranteed in its international agreement. On US corporates, Pence argued that Nike (NKE) has checked social conscience at the door regarding HK; says in siding with China, NBA has silenced free speech and is acting like a wholly owned subsidiary of an authoritarian regime. Pence concluded that China should never underestimate US resolve, and that US and China can and must work to share a peaceful and prosperous future, adding US will not allow challenges in US/China talks to foreclose practical cooperation. Despite some heavy words, China Global Times Editor (noted mouthpiece for the Chinese regime) said that Pence’s speech was mainly positive in regard to improving Sino-US relations.

* CHINA AGS PURCHASES: Reports had suggested that China offered to purchase at least USD 20bln in US agricultural products within a year, as part of the Phase 1 trade deal; analysts noted that the USD 20bln of purchases would restore imports of US farm goods to levels before Trump slapped tariffs on the nation. Stratfor's geopolitical analysts said the latest offer might increases the chances of both signs signing a partial trade deal at the APEC summit in November.

* ECB: As expected, given the close proximity of the September meeting (where a raft of measures was unveiled) and it being Draghi’s last appearance as head of the Bank in Frankfurt, this week’s policy announcement delivered little in the way of fireworks. All three key rates were left unchanged as expected with the Governing Council maintaining their guidance on rates, reinvestments, bond purchases and tiering. In terms of the press conference, asides from facing numerous questions about his legacy at the Bank, a bulk of Draghi’s focus was once again placed on the need for fiscal assistance in order to help assist the ECB’s monetary efforts. This will likely garner further focus during the Lagarde era at the Bank with the former IMF Chief seen as a more than credible candidate in helping managing relations with the bloc’s various governments. Elsewhere, Draghi’s commentary on the current state of the Eurozone economy provided little in the way of fresh insight with the President noting “that incoming data confirms the GC view of protracted weakness and prominent downside risks, and muted inflationary pressures”, whilst also concluding that “risks remain on the downside”. From a policy perspective, Draghi was also questioned on whether or not the Bank could become hampered by the prospect of bond scarcity given the open-ended nature of the ECB’s APP, however, Draghi downplayed this line of enquiry by stating that it will take quite a bit of time before this becomes a problem. Overall, this week’s announcement and press conference provided little in the way of insight to the future course of action at the Bank with a bulk of the focus more one of reflection as Mario Draghi prepares to hand over the baton to Christine Lagarde.

* MARKIT PMI (FLASH): US Services for October came in line with expectations at 51, inching up from the prior 50.9, whilst the Manufacturing component printed 51.5, beating the expected decline to 50.7 from the prior 51.1, altogether seeing the composite rise by 0.2 to 51.2. Markit noted “the fastest expansion of manufacturing production for six months”, although caveated that the forward-looking indicators remain subdued, “new work rose at the slowest pace since this index began in October 2009.” Over in Europe, Pantheon Macroeconomics note the “trivial” rise in the composite EZ figure to 50.2 from 50.1 (exp. 50.3). “The manufacturing PMI was unchanged at a poorly 45.7, while the services index edged slightly higher to 51.8 from 51.6 in September. The details aren’t pretty,” where the consultancy cites the weak new orders and production due to the manufacturing slump. The much-focused German figures remained dismal: Manufacturing printing 41.9 (exp. 42, prev. 41.7), whilst the Services component declined to 51.2, missing the expected 52.

* US NEW HOME SALES: The headline was in line with expectations at 701k, falling a touch from a revised down 706k. Pantheon Macroeconomics noted that this was the fourth consecutive month with sales running a little higher than has been implied by the lagged mortgage applications data. "The bigger picture is clear enough," Pantheon writes, "the trend in new home sales is rising, and the surge in mortgage purchase applications since the summer points to new cycle highs by the turn of the year, though a brief correction before then can’t be ruled out." The consultancy notes that the fall in mortgage rates is lifting demand, though it expects it to peak early next year, in the face of a sharp slowdown in payroll growth. "For now, though, sales are firm, and inventory is quite low, so we’re expecting a hefty increase in fourth quarter construction, captured in the residential investment component of GDP (alas it accounts for only 3.7% of the economy).”

* BREXIT: UK PM Johnson will table a motion on Monday, under the Fixed Term Parliament Act, to have an election on 12 December, under the assumption that the EU will offer a Brexit delay until the 31st January (although reports alleged France is pushing for a much shorter delay until 15th November). 2/3s (or 434) of MPs will need to vote in favour of an election; the SNP and Liberal Democrats have previously called for an election, although some reports suggested they may not vote with the government. Labour, despite claims they would back an election once “no deal is off the table” (presumably meaning when an extension is granted into 2020), may be more reticent, their poor position in the polls spurring some calls for the party to try to delay an election into 2020. The party have provided mixed signals as whips announced they would be abstaining the vote on Monday in an email to Labour MP’s, however Labour Leader Corbyn announced a final decision would come tomorrow or over the weekend. It was also noted that the Tory party would essentially go on strike if the vote is rejected, by doing the bare minimum in Parliament. The EU may also wait to announce its decision on a Brexit extension, until Monday, whilst UK PM Johnson calls to get get parliament on board. If parliament does thwart the government’s attempt to press for an election, talks of a “government of national unity” could re-emerge; previously the idea has not stuck due to Labour’s insistence that it be led by Labour Leader Corbyn and the Lib Dems opposition to Corbyn as PM. It is worth noting a recent ComRes poll which put the Labour Party ahead when voters were asked their voting intentions "the deadline for the UK to leave the EU has been extended beyond the 31st of October 2019" (Labour at 27%, Conservative 26%, Brexit Party 20%, Lib Dems: 18%). An election on 12th December would give Parliament time to pass the government’s WAB (Parliament would be dissolved on 6th November), however a number of journalists pointed out that the opposition would be reluctant to hand the government such a victory in the run up to an election.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.2% at 3010, NASDAQ-100 1% at 7967, Dow Jones -0.1% at 26806,

* S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.1%, Consumer Staples 0.3%, Energy -0.4%, Financials 0%, Health Care -0.6%, Industrials 0.1%, Information Technology 1.5%, Materials 0.4%, Telecommunication Services -0.7%, Utilities 0.4%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Microsoft (MSFT) reported strong earnings, with a slightly slower than expected growth rate in Azure as the only nagging point, seeing it bolster indices on the day. Tesla (TSLA) surged to highs of 20% in after-market trade following earnings which showed a surprise profit beat on EPS, and noting its Shanghai Gigafactory is working ahead of schedule, as is its Model Y, where it expects production expected by summer next year. Xilinx (XLNX) ultimately moved lower after guiding Q4 revenue well below estimates, although caveat by suggesting Q4 would be a trough. Lam Research (LRCX) beat on top and bottom line, forecasts the bottom range of its Q2 EPS and revenue guidance above street expectation. The strong figures and guidance led a boost to the semiconductor space which saw the SOX outperform its sub-index peers on Thursday. Both figures from LRCX & TSLA led gains to the Nasdaq 100, which outperformed its US peers. Align Technology (ALGN) traded higher following a beat on both EPS & revenue. Twitter (TWTR) plummeted over 20% on Thursday at one point on EPS and revenue misses, citing technical bugs hitting its top line. Baxter (BAX) traded lower as it announced an internal investigation due to financial misstatements. eBay (EBAY) lower despite EPS beat, due to softer guidance. PayPal (PYPL) surged despite softer guidance but a strong revenue print. Ford (F) tumbled as it cut its guidance, although the quarter was okay.

* WTI (Z9) SETTLES USD 0.26 HIGHER AT USD 56.23/BBL; BRENT (Z9) SETTLES USD 0.50 HIGHER AT USD 61.67/BBL: Oil prices moved higher on Thursday despite a lack of fresh demand, or supply, factor impetus and against dollar strength, where benchmarks gradually made gains throughout the session. The energy market seems to be extending its gains from Wednesday where the surprise draw in crude stocks reported by the EIA saw benchmarks gain around a buck and a half.

* US T-NOTE (Z9) SETTLED HALF A TICK LOWER AT 129.27. The T-Note again traded sideways in the lacklustre session, at least from a risk appetite perspective. The much feared/anticipated VP Pence speech on China took a rather balanced stance and provided no further indication for participants on how the trade war will pan out. The ECB was also a non-event given the last meeting’s fireworks. Earnings were mixed too, seeing equity bourses edge slightly higher, again little to sway participants either in or out of the debt complex. The US 7-year auction was fairly solid, stopping through by 0.7bps, covering above the 6-auction average, with a strong takedown, too – although the TPLEX didn’t blink.

* FX WRAP: USD traded firmer today with DXY breaking above 97.50 in the morning, the rally continued into the afternoon to see highs of 97.785 from overnight lows of 97.28. The US PMI data was relatively strong with the preliminary readings beating on Manufacturing and falling in line on services. China is also reportedly purchasing USD 20bln worth of agricultural goods, which is lower than the USD 40-50bln Trump said China would purchase as part of phase one of the deal, although no specific time frame was given. It was also noted that the USD 20bln in purchases is essentially what China was buying before the trade war. US VP Pence also followed up later with some rather punchy comments on Hong Kong and China, which may not go down to well with the Chinese. GBP was lower today retracing yesterday’s range trading from highs of 1.2949 to lows of 1.2785 driven by dollar strength, however some losses were pared back and the cross trades around the 1.2850 mark heading into ASIA-PAC. UK PM Johnson announced there will be a vote on Monday for a general election, although it is unlikely to pass as it appears Labour will reject the vote and abstain, although Corbyn did announce their final decision would come tomorrow or on the weekend. EUR saw choppy trade as it rose on better than expected French PMI data, however poor German PMI data reversed those gains. Draghi’s final policy meeting saw no fireworks as expected given the stimulus package introduced at its previous meeting, although EURUSD did rebound to post French PMI highs after he reiterated the importance of fiscal policy. Haven’s were firmer today, albeit, not so much against the buck given the strength in the greenback. XAU trades back above 1500, and JPY firmer against crosses, flat against the buck, CHF was weaker against the dollar, but firmer against other crosses. EMFX was weaker, with underperformance seen in TRY as it retraces some of its prior day gains. MXN, BRL & ZAR all ~0.2% weaker against the greenback.

* NORGES: Norges Bank maintained rates at 1.50% and reiterated the guidance from September, noting that the outlook for the period ahead is little changed. Noting that the upturn in the Norwegian economy is continuing ‘broadly in line with expectations, underlying inflation has been as projected’. As this meeting did not include updated forecasts or a press conference there is very little else to discuss from this meeting. Looking ahead Governor Olsen is scheduled to speak tomorrow at 08:00BST.

* RIKSBANK: Riksbank, as expected, left rates unchanged at -0.25%. However, against some expectations, the Bank maintained their hiking bias noting a 25bp hike in December to 0.0% is likely; following this, the repo rate has been altered to indicate rates will remain unchanged at this period – essentially signalling a ‘one and done’ move. On the release the SEK significantly strengthened vs. EUR with EUR/SEK printing a low of 10.6519 as the retention of the hiking bias was picked up. As such, a number of banks have altered their base case to show a hike in December of 25bp after-which rates will remain on hold for the period ahead. Regarding the repo rate forecast, this has actually been lowered for Q419 to -0.25% (due to a December hike, if it occurs, not coming into effect until January 8th); further out, the repo path has rates remaining unchanged at the 0.0% mark until Q4 2021, with a full 25bp hike not visible anywhere on the path. Looking ahead, focus turns to comments from Ohlsson and Floden tomorrow.

* CBRT: The CBRT cut its one-week repo rate by 250bps to 14%, well below the expected 15.5% and a greater cut than the lowest surveyed estimate of 14.5%. The Bank said the current monetary policy stance, to a large part, is consistent with the projected disinflation path, which it noted that recent forecast revisions suggest inflation is likely to materialize notably below the projections of the July inflation report by year-end. It attributed the domestic demand conditions and the level of monetary tightness as continuing to support the disinflation picture, adding that in order to keep disinflation in track with the targeted path, the continuation of a cautious monetary policy stance is required. However, ING believes that inflation will reverse higher after October due to base effects, as of such, the case for further easing in December has significantly weakened, where future easing should be carried at a more gradual pace following the recent over-delivery, the bank says.

PREVIEW: US to sell USD 32bln of 7-year notes on 24th October at 1800 BST/1300 BST
content:
THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will this week auction a new 2-year note (USD 40bln, Tue), a new 5-year note (USD 41bln, Wed), and a new 7-year note (USD 32bln, Thu); Analysts at UBS note that there are around USD 84bln of cash flows at the end-month settlement (excluding SOMA holdings), including around USD 75bln of redemptions and around USD 9bln of coupons

7-YEAR PREVIEW: The September auction was decent, stopping through the screens by 0.5bps (largest stop through since March). Analysts at SocGen say the 7-year note trades fair in asset swap compared to older 7s, though trades rich on the curve versus 5s and 10s. The bank also notes that the current when issued yield is trading above last month's stop out rate, which may provide some support for the auction. Additionally, it is worth keeping in mind that, earlier on Thursday, the ECB policy meeting may influence action heading into the auction, while desks will also be wary of ongoing Brexit headline risk.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: risk-off tone seeps in to super Central Bank (and PMI) Thursday
content:
USD

The Dollar gleaned some traction from a better than expected US Markit manufacturing PMI, but not really against safer-havens like the Yen and Gold that remained around 108.50 and Usd1500/oz respectively. Hence, the DXY’s firmer rebound to 97.700+ levels from just shy of 97.300 seemed to be more a function of broader risk aversion or defensive positioning amidst ongoing geopolitical, global trade and growth concerns, while Brexit uncertainty rumbles on as well.

NZD/AUD/GBP

The G10 underperformers as the Aussie and Kiwi handed back more of their recent gains vs the Greenback towards 0.6800 and 0.6375 respectively having topped out ahead of 0.6900 and 0.64500. No specific or new catalyst behind the retracement, but Cable’s latest pull-back of around 100 pips to retest 1.2840 support was accompanied by another stream of headlines related to the prospect of a GE and how long the EU might offer the UK in terms of a further Article 50 extension. On that note, a meeting in Brussels has been set for 10CET/9BST tomorrow and PM Johnson is currently in consultation with his political cabinet.

EUR/SEK/NOK/TRY/IDR

All eyeing October Central Bank policy gatherings, but with varying degrees of anticipation. The Euro was not looking for much from the ECB given the scale of stimulus rolled out or preannounced in September, and as rates were duly held with an almost identical accompanying statement attention quickly turned to President Draghi for his final post-meeting press conference/Q&A. His prepared text was also largely a carbon copy of the previous version, while questions were somewhat retrospective and focused on his 8 years in office, but Eur/Usd did rebound towards post-French PMI peaks after he reiterated the importance of fiscal policy before retreating and testing 1.1100 bids/support. Meanwhile, the Swedish Krona strengthened after the Riksbank stuck to its hawkish line and pencilled in December for a 25 bp repo hike to zero rather than a window somewhere around the turn of this year, but pared gains within a 10.7400-6520 band vs the single currency as the rate path was trimmed and the Bank caveated with potential to ease if the domestic economy deteriorates more than anticipated. The Norwegian Crown tagged along and hardly deviated when the Norges Bank essentially maintained its assessment and guidance from September, but the Turkish Lira was undermined by a bigger than expected CBRT cut (-250 bp vs -200 bp bottom end of consensus range) and retained an easing bias due to a weaker than previously envisaged inflation outlook. Finally, the BI took its cumulative easing to 100 bp with a 4th ¼ point cut, but in line with forecast and only marginally weighing on the Rupiah.

EM

Solid appreciation for the Real and a look at the psychological 4.0000 mark vs the Buck in wake of Senate approval for Brazil’s pension reform bill, albeit with some amendments.

Fixed and FX latest: more choppy trade in debt and currency markets
content: Disappointing US durable goods data chimed with dovish remarks from ECB President Draghi during the early part of his last press conference, and together prompted an uptick in bonds across the board. However, in similar vein to price action after September’s policy action and post-meeting comments Bunds have retreated as he reiterates that fiscal stimulus needs to pick up the stimulus baton, while Gilts have reversed course amidst headlines suggesting that the Labour Party won’t scupper another attempt by PM Johnson to hold a snap election and US Treasuries appear to be making room for impending 7 year supply. Prior to that though, Markit PMIs could well cause a stir given the see-saw moves prompted by EZ surveys earlier today. Elsewhere, equally erratic Dollar activity vs the Euro in particular, albeit still within a circa 1.1160-20 range, while the DXY flits around 97.500.

content: • In the second year of a potential final deal when all punitive tariffs are removed, those purchases could rise to USD 40bln - USD 50bln
analysis_details:
• US President had talked about how, as part of a phase 1 trade agreement, China would be buying up to USD 40-50bln worth of US agricultural goods per year - although he did not give a time frame over which these purchases would occur. Chinese officials had not previously put a exact number on these purchases, saying they would be buying agricultural goods according to domestic market demand.
  • Bloomberg's Donnan notes that USD 20bln per year is essentially what China was buying before the trade war.

subject: RANsquawk Central Banks - PREVIEW: ECB Monetary Policy Decision Due Thursday 24th October
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

This week’s policy announcement from the ECB will likely draw far less attention than the one in September which saw policymakers unveil a raft of easing measures to help aide the Eurozone economy. Instead, this week’s meeting will likely focus on recently announced measures, the need for fiscal assistance and Draghi’s tenure at the Bank in what will be his last meeting before handing over the reins to Christine Lagarde.

subject: Southwest Airlines Co (LUV) Q3 19 (USD): EPS 1.23 (exp. 1.08), Revenue 5.60 (exp. 5.64bln)
RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 24th October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European equities are firmer this morning after a choppy session following Flash PMIs
  • Riksbank and Norges Bank left rates unchanged as expected; Riksbank maintained December hiking bias – as such Scandi’s are firmer
  • UK PM Johnson reportedly faces increasing revolt from within his party over the threat of holding an election before delivering the Brexit
  • Looking ahead highlights include, US Durables, Initial Jobless Claims and Markit PMIs, ECB, and CBRT policy decisions, ECB’s Draghi, US 7yr supply
  • Earnings: Amazon, American Airlines, ComCast, Southwest Airlines, Raytheon, Intel, 3M, Visa, T-Mobile, Twitter, Christian Dior

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed after having failed to fully sustain the positive lead from Wall St with global markets heavily focused on earnings releases. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) were positive in which energy led the advances in Australia and with participants also engrossed in corporate updates, while sentiment in Tokyo was propped up by recent currency weakness and with double-digit percentage gains seen in Japan Display after Apple further extended an olive branch for the troubled screen manufacturer through shorter payment terms. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were mixed after the PBoC continued with its liquidity efforts albeit at a reduced amount and with China dismissing reports of replacing Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam as political rumours, while the KOSPI (flat) underperformed its regional peers for a bulk of the session following a miss on Q3 GDP. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat as they took their cue from the lacklustre trade in T-notes, with demand restricted by the upbeat risk sentiment Japanese stocks and following mixed results at the 20yr JGB auction.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 60bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0727 vs. Exp. 7.0701 (Prev. 7.0752)

South Korea GDP (Q3) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 1.0%). (Newswires) South Korea GDP (Q3) Y/Y 2.0% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.0%)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea said its leader Kim and US President Trump continue to have close relations and trust, but added contrary to Trump, US political circles remain hostile to North Korea and noted it will see how wisely US will pass end of the year. (KCNA)

US Defence Secretary Esper notes, in the context of the attacks on Saudi oil facilities, that the US does not seek war with Iran but is prepared and that Iran are threatening international navigation in the Gulf. (Newswires)

Saudi Minister of State for Foreign Affairs notes that a agreement between the Yemen Government and Houthis is imminent., AJA Breaking. (Twitter)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson reportedly faces increasing revolt from within his party over the threat of holding an election before delivering the Brexit. (The Sun) Opposition leader Corbyn has been urged to prevent an election until Spring 2020, as Labour claimed yesterday it could not trust PM Johnson over the date of a poll. (Telegraph)

Finnish PM Rinne notes that a majority, maybe all, of EU states are in favour of a Brexit extension, for now appears the EU can decide a extension in writing; EU Commission President in waiting Von der Leyen notes that the length is yet to be decided. (Newswires)

European Parliament group leaders are united on a flexible Brexit extension until January 31st 2020, with the option that this period could end earlier., Euro News' McCaffey. (Twitter)

Labour MP Bailey states that if PM Johnson was to go straight to a general election then of course we will be in favor of this., Times Webber. (Twitter)

UK Chancellor Javid suggested that he could name BoE Governor Carney’s successor prior to holding a snap election. (Times)

French Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Oct) 50.5 vs. Exp. 50.3 (Prev. 50.1)

- French Markit Services Flash PMI (Oct) 52.9 vs. Exp. 51.6 (Prev. 51.1)

German Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Oct) 41.9 vs. Exp. 42 (Prev. 41.7)

- Markit Services Flash PMI (Oct) 51.2 vs. Exp. 52 (Prev. 51.4)

EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Oct) 45.7 vs. Exp. 46 (Prev. 45.7)

- EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Oct) 51.8 vs. Exp. 51.9 (Prev. 51.6)

- The eurozone economy started the fourth quarter mired close to stagnation, with the flash PMI pointing to a quarterly GDP growth rate of just under 0.1%" says IHS

EQUITIES

Major European Bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%) are higher, although some choppiness was seen in wake of soft Eurozone PMI data (although France was a bright spot). “The eurozone economy started the fourth quarter mired close to stagnation, with the flash PMI pointing to a quarterly GDP growth rate of just under 0.1%” said IHS Markit. Looking ahead, markets await a slew of US earnings, including from the likes of Comcast, and the next ECB policy announcement. Sectors are in largely in the green, with the exception of Tech (-0.6%) and Telecoms (-0.8%), with notable weakness in Nokia (-19.8%) following earnings contributing to underperformance in the former. In terms of other individual movers; strong earnings from STMicroelectronics (+5.6%), Daimler (4.0%), Hermes (+1.5%), BASF (+1.8%) and AstraZeneca (+3.6%) saw their respective stock prices advance. Meanwhile, weak earnings from Puma (-2.7%), RBS (-2.2%) and Dassault Systemes (-5.3%). Elsewhere, EDF (+2.1%) was supported by the news that it can keep operating nuclear power plants with weld issues, according to the French Nuclear Authority. Porsche (+1.4%) moved higher on the news that the Co. has formed a strategic partnership with SAP (-0.3%), who opened higher but pared gains in line with the tech sector. In terms of broker moves, Rolls Royce (-4.2%) and Telia (-1.8%) moved lower on downgrades at JPM, while Ashmore Group (+1.6%) was bid on an upgrade at Investec.

Of note for Amazon (AMZN) - Democratic senators are asking the FTC to investigate the Co. over concerns it ignored security warnings about a vulnerability that enabled the hack of Capital One customer data. (WSJ)

FX

SEK/NOK/INR - The Swedish Crown has slipped from best levels, but remains bid after the Riksbank doubled down on repo rate hike guidance and signalled that a 25 bp move is likely in December vs a more flexible timeline covering the end of 2019 and early next year. However, the path beyond suggests no further policy normalisation and in recognition of heightened uncertainty surrounding growth and inflation overseas and on the domestic front, the Bank could cut or ease via other measures if necessary. Eur/Sek is holding near the base of a circa 10.7400-10.6510 range and still net down from pre-Riksbank levels around 10.7000, while Eur/Nok is hovering just under 10.1500 within 10.1680-10.1260 parameters in wake of the Norges Bank’s policy meeting that maintained an on hold stance after September’s ¼ point rise in the depo rate given the assessment that little has changed in the ensuing period. Elsewhere, the Indonesian Rupiah is modestly softer after the BI extended its run of consecutive eases to 4 and retained a dovish bias.

AUD/NZD - The major fall guys on little apparent or obvious in terms of negative news and a bearish catalysts, but the Aussie and Kiwi especially seem to have fallen prey to long liquidation and a turnaround in the technical landscape after failing to extend gains through/beyond big figure and psychological levels. Aud/Usd has lost momentum through 0.6850 and Nzd/Usd on a breach of 0.6400, while the Aud/Nzd cross has corrected a bit higher above 1.0650.

EUR/GBP - Nowhere near the biggest G10 movers on the day, but certainly rivalling others on price action given spikes in the single currency and Sterling to 1.1163 and 1.2950 vs the Dollar respectively at one stage followed by sharp/abrupt retreats to 1.1125 and 1.2880. For Eur/Usd, French PMIs were above forecast, but ultimately no more than a flash in the pan as preliminary surveys from Germany disappointed yet again and weighed on the pan Eurozone prints. Meanwhile, Cable’s rise and fall from grace came against the backdrop of latest Brexit and UK election headlines, but probably more on positioning and jitters awaiting the EU’s verdict on another A 50 extension and PM Johnson’s reaction. Back to the Euro, ECB President Draghi’s farewell meeting and press conference loom, but expectations are low in terms of anything pertinent on new policy or guidance.

JPY/CHF/CAD/DXY - All relatively subdued and lacking inspiration as the Yen meanders between 108.60-75 vs the Greenback, Franc pivots 0.9900, Loonie hovers just above 1.3100 and US Dollar index rebounds off a 97.278 low to 97.532 ahead of US data.

EM - The Lira is still eyeing Turkish-Syria developments and international interventions after recent gains on less angst from the US in wake of the ceasefire and President Trump promising to lift sanctions if peace prevails. However, the upcoming CBRT rate call will be watched for near term direction as forecast range from no change to a 200 bp cut – see our headline feed and Research Suite for more. Usd/Try currently straddling 5.7500.

Riksbank: U/C at -0.25% (Exp. -0.25%). Riksbank maintained their hiking bias which sees a hike towards years end – most probably a 25bp hike in December, afterwhich the rate will remain be unchaned at 0.0% for a prolonged period. Governor Ingves states that negative rates were an exceptional measure, which it is now appropriate to gradually exit.

Norges Bank: U/C at 1.50% (Exp. 1.50%). Bank noted that the outlook and balance of risks indicates rates will most likely remain at present levels for the period ahead; a reiteration of the September guidance.

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

- EUR/USD: 1.1020-35 (1.4BLN), 1.1100-10 (1.3BLN), 1.1125-35 (560M), 1.11.40-50 (500M), 1.200 (360M), 1.1220-35 (1BLN)

- AUD/USD: 0.6770-75 (400M), 0.6795-0.6800 (450M), 0.6825-40 (750M)

- USD/JPY: 108.00 (1BLN), 108.30-35 (750M), 108.50 (320M), 108.65-80 (1BLN)

FIXED INCOME

ECB, CBRT, US data and the 7 year Treasury auction still to come, but bonds have already marked out decent ranges and clocked up some hefty price moves. Indeed, Bunds were wrong-footed by French PMI beats and are now back below par, albeit off worst levels within a 171.16-77 range, while Gilts have been pulled pillar to post in sympathy, but also eyeing breaking Brexit headlines and Sterling fortunes between 131.80-132.37. However, US Treasuries are showing relative resilient or a reticence to being whip-sawed awaiting independent drivers in the form of data and the 7 year raffle.

COMMODITIES                                      

The crude complex is slightly softer, amidst a slight pull-back from yesterday’s post-EIA Inventory data induced highs, with some choppiness seen in wake of mostly weaker than expected Eurozone PMI data. To the downside, technicians will be eyeing support at USD 54.90/bbl and USD 60.70/bbl for WTI Dec’ 19 and Brent Dec’ 19 futures respectively (11th October highs for both); to the upside yesterday’s highs for each contract are at USD 61.30/bbl and USD 56.10/bbl respectively. In terms of crude specific fundamentals, the news flow has been light. Moving to metals; Gold is slight lower, despite soft Eurozone data. Copper, meanwhile, is holding on to decent gains made yesterday; Chilean miner Codelco said that some of its shipments may be delayed as a result of the ongoing protests and strikes in the country, that have seen operations affected in at least two mines and a smelter. Despite being pressured in recent weeks, as global economic data has continued to show deterioration (particularly in China, the largest buyer of the red metal), the unrest in Chile continues to provide support to prices, notes ING.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 24th October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European equities are firmer this morning after a choppy session following Flash PMIs
  • Riksbank and Norges Bank left rates unchanged as expected; Riksbank maintained December hiking bias – as such Scandi’s are firmer
  • UK PM Johnson reportedly faces increasing revolt from within his party over the threat of holding an election before delivering the Brexit
  • Looking ahead highlights include, US Durables, Initial Jobless Claims and Markit PMIs, ECB, and CBRT policy decisions, ECB’s Draghi, US 7yr supply
  • Earnings: Amazon, American Airlines, ComCast, Southwest Airlines, Raytheon, Intel, 3M, Visa, T-Mobile, Twitter, Christian Dior

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed after having failed to fully sustain the positive lead from Wall St with global markets heavily focused on earnings releases. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) were positive in which energy led the advances in Australia and with participants also engrossed in corporate updates, while sentiment in Tokyo was propped up by recent currency weakness and with double-digit percentage gains seen in Japan Display after Apple further extended an olive branch for the troubled screen manufacturer through shorter payment terms. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were mixed after the PBoC continued with its liquidity efforts albeit at a reduced amount and with China dismissing reports of replacing Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam as political rumours, while the KOSPI (flat) underperformed its regional peers for a bulk of the session following a miss on Q3 GDP. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat as they took their cue from the lacklustre trade in T-notes, with demand restricted by the upbeat risk sentiment Japanese stocks and following mixed results at the 20yr JGB auction.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 60bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0727 vs. Exp. 7.0701 (Prev. 7.0752)

South Korea GDP (Q3) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 1.0%). (Newswires) South Korea GDP (Q3) Y/Y 2.0% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.0%)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea said its leader Kim and US President Trump continue to have close relations and trust, but added contrary to Trump, US political circles remain hostile to North Korea and noted it will see how wisely US will pass end of the year. (KCNA)

US Defence Secretary Esper notes, in the context of the attacks on Saudi oil facilities, that the US does not seek war with Iran but is prepared and that Iran are threatening international navigation in the Gulf. (Newswires)

Saudi Minister of State for Foreign Affairs notes that a agreement between the Yemen Government and Houthis is imminent., AJA Breaking. (Twitter)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson reportedly faces increasing revolt from within his party over the threat of holding an election before delivering the Brexit. (The Sun) Opposition leader Corbyn has been urged to prevent an election until Spring 2020, as Labour claimed yesterday it could not trust PM Johnson over the date of a poll. (Telegraph)

Finnish PM Rinne notes that a majority, maybe all, of EU states are in favour of a Brexit extension, for now appears the EU can decide a extension in writing; EU Commission President in waiting Von der Leyen notes that the length is yet to be decided. (Newswires)

European Parliament group leaders are united on a flexible Brexit extension until January 31st 2020, with the option that this period could end earlier., Euro News' McCaffey. (Twitter)

Labour MP Bailey states that if PM Johnson was to go straight to a general election then of course we will be in favor of this., Times Webber. (Twitter)

UK Chancellor Javid suggested that he could name BoE Governor Carney’s successor prior to holding a snap election. (Times)

French Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Oct) 50.5 vs. Exp. 50.3 (Prev. 50.1)

- French Markit Services Flash PMI (Oct) 52.9 vs. Exp. 51.6 (Prev. 51.1)

German Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Oct) 41.9 vs. Exp. 42 (Prev. 41.7)

- Markit Services Flash PMI (Oct) 51.2 vs. Exp. 52 (Prev. 51.4)

EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Oct) 45.7 vs. Exp. 46 (Prev. 45.7)

- EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Oct) 51.8 vs. Exp. 51.9 (Prev. 51.6)

- The eurozone economy started the fourth quarter mired close to stagnation, with the flash PMI pointing to a quarterly GDP growth rate of just under 0.1%" says IHS

EQUITIES

Major European Bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%) are higher, although some choppiness was seen in wake of soft Eurozone PMI data (although France was a bright spot). “The eurozone economy started the fourth quarter mired close to stagnation, with the flash PMI pointing to a quarterly GDP growth rate of just under 0.1%” said IHS Markit. Looking ahead, markets await a slew of US earnings, including from the likes of Comcast, and the next ECB policy announcement. Sectors are in largely in the green, with the exception of Tech (-0.6%) and Telecoms (-0.8%), with notable weakness in Nokia (-19.8%) following earnings contributing to underperformance in the former. In terms of other individual movers; strong earnings from STMicroelectronics (+5.6%), Daimler (4.0%), Hermes (+1.5%), BASF (+1.8%) and AstraZeneca (+3.6%) saw their respective stock prices advance. Meanwhile, weak earnings from Puma (-2.7%), RBS (-2.2%) and Dassault Systemes (-5.3%). Elsewhere, EDF (+2.1%) was supported by the news that it can keep operating nuclear power plants with weld issues, according to the French Nuclear Authority. Porsche (+1.4%) moved higher on the news that the Co. has formed a strategic partnership with SAP (-0.3%), who opened higher but pared gains in line with the tech sector. In terms of broker moves, Rolls Royce (-4.2%) and Telia (-1.8%) moved lower on downgrades at JPM, while Ashmore Group (+1.6%) was bid on an upgrade at Investec.

Of note for Amazon (AMZN) - Democratic senators are asking the FTC to investigate the Co. over concerns it ignored security warnings about a vulnerability that enabled the hack of Capital One customer data. (WSJ)

FX

SEK/NOK/INR - The Swedish Crown has slipped from best levels, but remains bid after the Riksbank doubled down on repo rate hike guidance and signalled that a 25 bp move is likely in December vs a more flexible timeline covering the end of 2019 and early next year. However, the path beyond suggests no further policy normalisation and in recognition of heightened uncertainty surrounding growth and inflation overseas and on the domestic front, the Bank could cut or ease via other measures if necessary. Eur/Sek is holding near the base of a circa 10.7400-10.6510 range and still net down from pre-Riksbank levels around 10.7000, while Eur/Nok is hovering just under 10.1500 within 10.1680-10.1260 parameters in wake of the Norges Bank’s policy meeting that maintained an on hold stance after September’s ¼ point rise in the depo rate given the assessment that little has changed in the ensuing period. Elsewhere, the Indonesian Rupiah is modestly softer after the BI extended its run of consecutive eases to 4 and retained a dovish bias.

AUD/NZD - The major fall guys on little apparent or obvious in terms of negative news and a bearish catalysts, but the Aussie and Kiwi especially seem to have fallen prey to long liquidation and a turnaround in the technical landscape after failing to extend gains through/beyond big figure and psychological levels. Aud/Usd has lost momentum through 0.6850 and Nzd/Usd on a breach of 0.6400, while the Aud/Nzd cross has corrected a bit higher above 1.0650.

EUR/GBP - Nowhere near the biggest G10 movers on the day, but certainly rivalling others on price action given spikes in the single currency and Sterling to 1.1163 and 1.2950 vs the Dollar respectively at one stage followed by sharp/abrupt retreats to 1.1125 and 1.2880. For Eur/Usd, French PMIs were above forecast, but ultimately no more than a flash in the pan as preliminary surveys from Germany disappointed yet again and weighed on the pan Eurozone prints. Meanwhile, Cable’s rise and fall from grace came against the backdrop of latest Brexit and UK election headlines, but probably more on positioning and jitters awaiting the EU’s verdict on another A 50 extension and PM Johnson’s reaction. Back to the Euro, ECB President Draghi’s farewell meeting and press conference loom, but expectations are low in terms of anything pertinent on new policy or guidance.

JPY/CHF/CAD/DXY - All relatively subdued and lacking inspiration as the Yen meanders between 108.60-75 vs the Greenback, Franc pivots 0.9900, Loonie hovers just above 1.3100 and US Dollar index rebounds off a 97.278 low to 97.532 ahead of US data.

EM - The Lira is still eyeing Turkish-Syria developments and international interventions after recent gains on less angst from the US in wake of the ceasefire and President Trump promising to lift sanctions if peace prevails. However, the upcoming CBRT rate call will be watched for near term direction as forecast range from no change to a 200 bp cut – see our headline feed and Research Suite for more. Usd/Try currently straddling 5.7500.

Riksbank: U/C at -0.25% (Exp. -0.25%). Riksbank maintained their hiking bias which sees a hike towards years end – most probably a 25bp hike in December, afterwhich the rate will remain be unchaned at 0.0% for a prolonged period. Governor Ingves states that negative rates were an exceptional measure, which it is now appropriate to gradually exit.

Norges Bank: U/C at 1.50% (Exp. 1.50%). Bank noted that the outlook and balance of risks indicates rates will most likely remain at present levels for the period ahead; a reiteration of the September guidance.

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

- EUR/USD: 1.1020-35 (1.4BLN), 1.1100-10 (1.3BLN), 1.1125-35 (560M), 1.11.40-50 (500M), 1.200 (360M), 1.1220-35 (1BLN)

- AUD/USD: 0.6770-75 (400M), 0.6795-0.6800 (450M), 0.6825-40 (750M)

- USD/JPY: 108.00 (1BLN), 108.30-35 (750M), 108.50 (320M), 108.65-80 (1BLN)

FIXED INCOME

Indeed, Bunds were wrong-footed by French PMI beats and are now back below par, albeit off worst levels within a 171.16-77 range, while Gilts have been pulled pillar to post in sympathy, but also eyeing breaking Brexit headlines and Sterling fortunes between 131.80-132.37. However, US Treasuries are showing relative resilient or a reticence to being whip-sawed awaiting independent drivers in the form of data and the 7 year raffle.

COMMODITIES                                      

The crude complex is slightly softer, amidst a slight pull-back from yesterday’s post-EIA Inventory data induced highs, with some choppiness seen in wake of mostly weaker than expected Eurozone PMI data. To the downside, technicians will be eyeing support at USD 54.90/bbl and USD 60.70/bbl for WTI Dec’ 19 and Brent Dec’ 19 futures respectively (11th October highs for both); to the upside yesterday’s highs for each contract are at USD 61.30/bbl and USD 56.10/bbl respectively. In terms of crude specific fundamentals, the news flow has been light. Moving to metals; Gold is slight lower, despite soft Eurozone data. Copper, meanwhile, is holding on to decent gains made yesterday; Chilean miner Codelco said that some of its shipments may be delayed as a result of the ongoing protests and strikes in the country, that have seen operations affected in at least two mines and a smelter. Despite being pressured in recent weeks, as global economic data has continued to show deterioration (particularly in China, the largest buyer of the red metal), the unrest in Chile continues to provide support to prices, notes ING.

content: Encouraging if not outright upbeat French PMIs have pulled Eurozone bonds back into negative territory and down to new intraday lows (OATs at 167.76 and Bunds 171.16), with some spill-over selling in Gilts that were already under pressure after their return to Liffe and an initial uptick from Thursday’s 132.18 close. The 10 year UK benchmark retreated 38 ticks to 131.80 before bouncing quite firmly and reclaiming 132.00 alongside peers as Germany’s surveys disappointed again, as deteriorating services activity overshadows a marginal improvement in manufacturing, but still deep in contraction. Back to Liffe, Short Sterling contracts are choppy in a tight band around yesterday’s closes ahead of UK mortgage approvals, though far more interested in what is going on elsewhere ahead of the EU’s response to the latest Article 50 delay request.

subject: Bunds: probing above parity pre-PMIs and ‘perfunctory’ ECB policy meeting
content: A measured and relatively mild recovery from opening Eurex lows and extended losses to 171.43 at one stage (-24 ticks) has seen the 10 year German debt future trade 10 ticks above Wednesday’s settlement more recently. However, activity is muted awaiting today’s busy schedule headlined by flash PMIs and multiple Central Bank policy meetings including the ECB, but probably overshadowed by the Riksbank, Norges Bank and most likely the CBRT in terms of action and fresh guidance. The US agenda is also full and rounds off with the last of this week’s supply via Usd32 bn 7 year notes that normally go down well with foreign buyers.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

24th October 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed after having failed to fully sustain the positive lead from Wall St with global markets heavily focused on earnings releases. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) were positive in which energy led the advances in Australia and with participants also engrossed in corporate updates, while sentiment in Tokyo was propped up by recent currency weakness and with double-digit percentage gains seen in Japan Display after Apple further extended an olive branch for the troubled screen manufacturer through shorter payment terms. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were mixed after the PBoC continued with its liquidity efforts albeit at a reduced amount and with China dismissing reports of replacing Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam as political rumours, while the KOSPI (flat) underperformed its regional peers for a bulk of the session following a miss on Q3 GDP. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat as they took their cue from the lacklustre trade in T-notes, with demand restricted by the upbeat risk sentiment Japanese stocks and following mixed results at the 20yr JGB auction.

FTSE 100

Just Eat (JE/ LN) - Shareholder Aberdeen Standard (SLA LN) has suggested that Prosus should pay an additional GBP 1bln to takeover the Co. (Telegraph)

 

BROKER MOVES

 

DAX

Daimler (DAI GY) – Q3 revenue EUR 43.3bln vs. Exp. EUR 43.1bln, EBIT EUR 2.69bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.54bln, net EUR 1.81bln. Co. affirms FY19 EBIT to be ‘significantly below’; expects unit sales around prev. and revenue slightly above prev.. CEO states we must significantly reduce costs, Truck division expects revenue in magnitude of prev., division was impacted by European and NA downturn; truck division is to cut jobs in Mexico and US. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 24th October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mixed after having failed to fully sustain the positive lead from Wall St with global markets heavily focused on earnings releases
  • UK PM Johnson reportedly faces increasing revolt from within his party over the threat of holding an election before delivering the Brexit
  • EU Diplomats are to discuss the UK's extension on Friday and say that an extension until 31 January is most likely
  • US President Trump said Turkey told the US that they will make the ceasefire permanent and the US will remove all sanctions on Turkey
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Eurozone Markit PMIs, US Durables, Initial Jobless Claims and Markit PMIs, ECB, Norges Bank, Riksbank and CBRT policy decisions, ECB’s Draghi, Riksbank’s Ingves and Jansson, US 7yr supply
  • Earnings: Amazon, American Airlines, ComCast, Southwest Airlines, Raytheon, Intel, 3M, Visa, T-Mobile, Twitter, Xcel Energy, Roper Tech, Danaher, Gilead, Daimler, STMicroelectronics, BASF, Puma, Eni, Saipem, Nokia, Dassault Systemes, Boliden, Christian Dior, Scor, Equinor, AstraZeneca

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed after having failed to fully sustain the positive lead from Wall St with global markets heavily focused on earnings releases. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) were positive in which energy led the advances in Australia and with participants also engrossed in corporate updates, while sentiment in Tokyo was propped up by recent currency weakness and with double-digit percentage gains seen in Japan Display after Apple further extended an olive branch for the troubled screen manufacturer through shorter payment terms. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were mixed after the PBoC continued with its liquidity efforts albeit at a reduced amount and with China dismissing reports of replacing Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam as political rumours, while the KOSPI (flat) underperformed its regional peers for a bulk of the session following a miss on Q3 GDP. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat as they took their cue from the lacklustre trade in T-notes, with demand restricted by the upbeat risk sentiment Japanese stocks and following mixed results at the 20yr JGB auction.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 60bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0727 vs. Exp. 7.0701 (Prev. 7.0752)

South Korea GDP (Q3) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 1.0%). (Newswires) South Korea GDP (Q3) Y/Y 2.0% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.0%)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson reportedly faces increasing revolt from within his party over the threat of holding an election before delivering the Brexit. (The Sun) Opposition leader Corbyn has been urged to prevent an election until Spring 2020, as Labour claimed yesterday it could not trust PM Johnson over the date of a poll. (Telegraph)

EU Diplomats are to discuss the UK's extension on Friday and say that an extension until 31 January is most likely, while it was separately reported that EU27 are in favour of a written procedure, meaning no emergency meeting although France and some others still prefer a short extension. EU's Verhofstadt said the Steering Group is of the opinion that a flextension, not going beyond the 31st January, is the only way forward. (Newswires/BuzzFeed) French President Macron is reportedly demanding a new Brexit deadline of 15th November, while a UK lawmaker source said PM Johnson told MPs that he had asked French President Macron to block the extension request. (Telegraph/BBC)

UK Chancellor Javid suggested that he could name BoE Governor Carney’s successor prior to holding a snap election. (Times)

UK retailers shed 85k jobs in the past year as weak consumer demand, increasing costs and switch to online shopping has added to the pressures for business. (Guardian) ECB said they have no objection to the appointment of Italy's Panetta to the Governing Council who once appointed, will succeed ECB's Coeure. (Newswires)

FX

DXY was subdued and trickled to a sub-97.50 level amid mild strength in its major counterparts in which EUR/USD maintained recent gains ahead of today’s ECB where President Draghi is unlikely to provide any fireworks in his last hurrah at the helm of the central bank. GBP/USD was also slightly firmer and reclaimed the 1.2900 handle as prospects of a no-deal Brexit continued to shrink with EU diplomats set to discuss the extension on Friday and a delay until January 31st seen as the most likely outcome. Elsewhere, USD/JPY mildly retraced some of yesterday’s advances but with the pullback limited by the positive risk tone and antipodeans were mixed as the recent upside in commodities provided a floor for AUD/USD, while NZD/USD underperformed and tested 0.6400 to the downside where there is a mid-size option expiry for today’s New York cut.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful with a mild pullback seen in WTI crude futures as the advances following a surprise draw in EIA crude stockpiles, was eventually stalled by resistance at the USD 56.00/bbl level and as Asia markets failed to fully sustain the optimism from US. Elsewhere, gold prices were steady with a subdued greenback keeping prices afloat, while copper was off yesterday’s best levels but with downside limited amid the mixed risk tone and early strength in Chinese commodity prices.

GEOPOLITICS

 

US President Trump said Turkey told the US that they will make the ceasefire permanent and the US will remove all sanctions on Turkey, unless something happens that the US is not happy with. (Newswires)

North Korea said its leader Kim and US President Trump continue to have close relations and trust, but added contrary to Trump, US political circles remain hostile to North Korea and noted it will see how wisely US will pass end of the year. (KCNA)

US 

T-Notes failed to show any conviction on either side throughout Wednesday trade despite the US 5-year auction appearing solid as it stopped through 0.4bps with a B/C of 2.41, higher than the 6-auction average of 2.37x. Indirect’s took a large portion of 65.7%, above the average 58%. Directs took 11.5% lower than the average take of 16.7%, which left dealers taking a rather small 22.8% in comparison to the 25.3% 6-auction average. At settlement yields were fractionally lower. US T-note (Z9) settled 1+ ticks higher at 129.27+.

NY Fed increased the amount offered in its overnight repo-operations to at least USD 120bln from USD 75bln starting Thursday and the term repos on the 24th and 29th will be at least USD 45bln. (Newswires)

content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly higher as the region takes mild impetus from the positive lead from Wall St with global markets heavily focused on earnings releases. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) are positive with energy stocks leading the advances in Australia following similar outperformance of the sector stateside on the back of a bullish EIA inventory report and with participants also engrossed in corporate updates, while sentiment in Tokyo is propped up by recent currency weakness and with double-digit percentage gains seen in Japan Display after Apple further extended an olive branch for the troubled screen manufacturer through shorter payment terms. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) are afloat after the PBoC continued with its liquidity efforts albeit at a reduced amount and with China dismissing reports of replacing Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam as political rumours, although the KOSPI (-0.2%) underperforms its regional peers following a miss on Q3 GDP.

In FX markets, the DXY remains subdued and has slipped to a sub-97.50 level amid mild strength in its major counterparts with EUR/USD prodding higher ahead of today’s ECB where President Draghi is unlikely to provide any fireworks in his last hurrah at the helm of the central bank. GBP/USD is also slightly firmer and reclaimed the 1.2900 handle as prospects of a no-deal Brexit continue to shrink with EU diplomats to discuss the extension on Friday and a delay until January 31st seen as the most likely outcome. Elsewhere, USD/JPY mildly retraced some of yesterday’s gains but with the pullback limited by the positive risk tone, while AUD/USD and NZD/USD consolidate as the recent upside in commodities and gains in stocks provide a floor for the high-beta currencies.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat as they take their cue from the lacklustre trade in T-notes, with demand restricted by the upbeat risk sentiment and ahead of the 20yr JGB auction later.
